Generation III.Ruby: Duskull can pass through any wall no matter how thick it may be. Once this Pok é mon chooses a target, it will doggedly pursue the intended victim until the break of dawn.
Generation III.Sapphire: Duskull wanders lost among the deep darkness of midnight. There is an oft-told admonishment given to misbehaving children that this Pok é mon will spirit away bad children who earn scoldings from their mothers.
Generation III.Emerald: A glare from its single scarlet eye makes even burly grown-ups freeze in utter fear. It is a nocturnal Pok é mon that roams about under the cloak of darkness.
Generation III.FireRed: Making itself invisible, it silently sneaks up to prey. It has the ability to slip through thick walls.
Generation III.LeafGreen: Making itself invisible, it silently sneaks up to prey. It has the ability to slip through thick walls.

Generation IV.Diamond: It doggedly pursues its prey wherever it goes. However, the chase is abandoned at sunrise.
Generation IV.Pearl: It doggedly pursues its prey wherever it goes. However, the chase is abandoned at sunrise.
Generation IV.Platinum: It loves the crying of children. It startles bad kids by passing through walls and making them cry.
Generation IV.HeartGold: If it finds bad children who won't listen to their parents, it will spirit them away--or so it's said.
Generation IV.SoulSilver: If it finds bad children who won't listen to their parents, it will spirit them away--or so it's said.

Generation VI.Y: If it finds bad children who won't listen to their parents, it will spirit them away--or so it's said.

Generation VIII.Sword: If it finds bad children who won't listen to their parents, it will spirit them away—or so it's said.

Generation VIII.Brilliant Diamond: It doggedly pursues its prey wherever the prey goes. However, the chase is abandoned at sunrise.
Generation VIII.Shining Pearl: It doggedly pursues its prey wherever the prey goes. However, the chase is abandoned at sunrise.
Generation VIII.Legends: Arceus: I've heard that the children of Hisui all begin to behave once they've been told the story of how this Pokémon roams about before the witching hour to spirit away misbehaving children.

Generation IX.Scarlet: In the dead of night, these Pokémon wander through towns in search of children, whose vital energy is a Duskull's favorite food.
Generation IX.Violet: Duskull's victims suffer an intense chill as the Pokémon siphons their life-force away, glaring at them with its bright red eye all the while.
